question_details.query: What are some effective non-chemical alternatives for managing invasive water primrose in European wetlands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, non-chemical alternatives for managing invasive water primrose include physical removal and biological control methods. Physical removal (Action ID 1138) shows mixed results: a study in the USA found that hand pulling and raking water primrose failed to reduce its abundance, whereas hand-pulling from the margins of a pond eradicated a smaller population of water primrose. Biological control using co-evolved, host specific herbivores (Action ID 1135) has shown promise: a controlled, replicated field study in China found a flea beetle caused heavy feeding destruction when added to field cages containing prostrate water primrose seedlings, and was specific to the prostrate water primrose and Indian toothcup. Additionally, a replicated, before-and-after field study in the USA found that introduction of flea beetles to a pond significantly reduced the abundance of large-flower primrose-willow. Other potential non-chemical methods mentioned include flame treatment (Action ID 1143), environmental control such as shading, altered flow, altered rooting depth, or dredging (Action ID 1147), public education (Action ID 1148), excavation of banks (Action ID 1146), biological control using native herbivores (Action ID 1136), and biological control using fungal-based herbicides (Action ID 1137), though no evidence was found for the effectiveness of these latter methods.
summary_statements: Non-chemical alternatives for managing invasive water primrose include physical removal and biological control methods.
Physical removal of invasive water primrose shows mixed results.
A study in the USA found that hand pulling and raking water primrose failed to reduce the water primrose's abundance.
Hand-pulling from the margins of a pond eradicated a smaller population of water primrose.
Biological control using co-evolved, host specific herbivores has shown promise for managing invasive water primrose.
A controlled, replicated field study in China found a flea beetle caused heavy feeding destruction when added to field cages containing prostrate water primrose seedlings.
The flea beetle in the China study was specific to the prostrate water primrose and Indian toothcup.
A replicated, before-and-after field study in the USA found that the introduction of flea beetles to a pond significantly reduced the abundance of large-flower primrose-willow.

Other potential non-chemical methods for managing invasive water primrose include flame treatment, environmental control, public education, excavation of banks, biological control using native herbivores, and biological control using fungal-based herbicides.
Environmental control methods can include shading, altered flow, altered rooting depth, or dredging.

No evidence was found for the effectiveness of flame treatment, environmental control, public education, excavation of banks, biological control using native herbivores, or biological control using fungal-based herbicides.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of altering water properties like salinity or temperature to control invasive Asian clams and Ponto-Caspian gammarids?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For Asian clams, a controlled laboratory study in the USA found that temperatures of 36°C or higher killed Asian clams within or after four days (Action 1116). Regarding salinity, a controlled, replicated laboratory study conducted in the USA found that Asian clams were killed (100% mortality) when exposed to high salinities (18-34‰) (Action 1115). For Ponto-Caspian gammarids, temperature control showed effectiveness, as a controlled laboratory study from the UK found that heating water to >36°C killed all shrimps after 15 minutes exposure and at >43°C all shrimps died immediately (Action 1092). However, salinity control showed mixed results for gammarids, as one of two replicated laboratory studies (one controlled) in Canada and the UK found that increasing the salinity level of water killed the majority of invasive shrimp within five hours, while one found that increased salinity did not kill invasive killer shrimp (Action 1091).
summary_statements: A controlled laboratory study in the USA found that temperatures of 36°C or higher killed Asian clams within or after four days.
A controlled, replicated laboratory study conducted in the USA found that Asian clams were killed when exposed to high salinities of 18-34‰.
For Ponto-Caspian gammarids, temperature control showed effectiveness.
A controlled laboratory study from the UK found that heating water to greater than 36°C killed all Ponto-Caspian gammarids after 15 minutes of exposure.
A controlled laboratory study from the UK found that at temperatures greater than 43°C all Ponto-Caspian gammarids died immediately.
Salinity control showed mixed results for Ponto-Caspian gammarids.
One of two replicated laboratory studies in Canada and the UK found that increasing the salinity level of water killed the majority of invasive shrimp within five hours.
One replicated laboratory study found that increased salinity did not kill invasive killer shrimp.

question_details.query: In shallow European ponds, what are some effective alternatives to biocides for controlling invasive brown and black bullhead populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, several alternatives to biocides have been identified for controlling invasive brown and black bullhead populations in shallow European ponds, though scientific evidence for most methods is limited. Netting using double fyke nets has demonstrated effectiveness, with a replicated study from 1999-2000 in shallow interconnected ponds in a nature reserve in Belgium showing that double fyke nets could be used to significantly reduce the population of brown bullhead measuring over 8cm (Action 1051). Other potential alternatives that have been identified but lack scientific evidence include: draining invaded waterbodies (Action 1078), using a combination of netting and electrofishing (Action 1080), electrofishing alone (Action 1079), increasing carbon dioxide concentrations (Action 1082), biological control using native predators (Action 1053), and trapping using sound or pheromonal lures (Action 1081). While these methods represent potential alternatives to biocides, research evidence for their effectiveness in controlling invasive bullhead populations is currently absent from the available literature.
summary_statements: Several alternatives to biocides have been identified for controlling invasive brown and black bullhead populations in shallow European ponds.
Scientific evidence for most alternative methods of controlling invasive bullhead populations is limited.
Netting using double fyke nets has demonstrated effectiveness in controlling invasive bullhead populations.

A replicated study from 1999-2000 in shallow interconnected ponds in a Belgian nature reserve showed that double fyke nets could be used to significantly reduce the population of brown bullhead measuring over 8cm.
Draining invaded waterbodies is a potential alternative for controlling invasive bullhead populations that lacks scientific evidence.
Using a combination of netting and electrofishing is a potential alternative for controlling invasive bullhead populations that lacks scientific evidence.
Using electrofishing alone is a potential alternative for controlling invasive bullhead populations that lacks scientific evidence.
Increasing carbon dioxide concentrations is a potential alternative for controlling invasive bullhead populations that lacks scientific evidence.
Biological control using native predators is a potential alternative for controlling invasive bullhead populations that lacks scientific evidence.
Trapping using sound or pheromonal lures is a potential alternative for controlling invasive bullhead populations that lacks scientific evidence.
Research evidence for the effectiveness of many potential alternatives to biocides in controlling invasive bullhead populations is currently absent from the available literature.

question_details.query: For controlling Crassula helmsii in the UK, what are the most and least effective non-physical control methods documented?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on documented studies in the UK, the most effective non-physical control methods for Crassula helmsii are chemical treatments with specific herbicides and salt water applications. Glyphosate showed effectiveness in seven studies, with one study demonstrating a 98% reduction when combined with diquat (Action 1279). Three out of four studies found that diquat or diquat alginate reduced cover or eradicated submerged C. helmsii (Action 1279). Salt water treatment showed high effectiveness, with two replicated controlled container trials and two before-and-after field trials finding that seawater eradicated C. helmsii (Action 1288). Among combination approaches, covering with carpet followed by glyphosate treatment killed 80% of the plant (Action 1313).

The least effective non-physical control methods documented include hydrogen peroxide, which in one controlled study using tank trials did not control C. helmsii (Action 1281). Aquatic dye application to reduce light levels was found ineffective, with one replicated controlled study showing it did not reduce coverage (Action 1293). Some herbicides showed limited effectiveness: dichlobenil led to only partial biomass reduction in one out of two studies (Action 1279), and terbutryne only partially reduced biomass of submerged C. helmsii in container trials (Action 1279). Grazing showed inconsistent results, with one study finding reduced abundance when grazing was excluded, while another found no difference between grazed and ungrazed plots (Action 1301).
summary_statements: Based on documented studies in the UK, the most effective non-physical control methods for Crassula helmsii are chemical treatments with specific herbicides and salt water applications.
Glyphosate showed effectiveness in seven studies for controlling Crassula helmsii.
One study demonstrated a 98% reduction of Crassula helmsii when glyphosate was combined with diquat.
Three out of four studies found that diquat or diquat alginate reduced cover or eradicated submerged Crassula helmsii.
Salt water treatment showed high effectiveness in controlling Crassula helmsii.
Two replicated controlled container trials and two before-and-after field trials found that seawater eradicated Crassula helmsii.
Among combination approaches, covering Crassula helmsii with carpet followed by glyphosate treatment killed 80% of the plant.
The least effective non-physical control methods documented for Crassula helmsii include hydrogen peroxide.
One controlled study using tank trials found that hydrogen peroxide did not control Crassula helmsii.
Aquatic dye application to reduce light levels was found to be an ineffective control method for Crassula helmsii.
One replicated controlled study showed that aquatic dye application did not reduce Crassula helmsii coverage.
Some herbicides showed limited effectiveness in controlling Crassula helmsii.
The herbicide dichlobenil led to only partial biomass reduction of Crassula helmsii in one out of two studies.
The herbicide terbutryne only partially reduced the biomass of submerged Crassula helmsii in container trials.
Grazing as a control method for Crassula helmsii showed inconsistent results.
One study found a reduced abundance of Crassula helmsii when grazing was excluded.
Another study found no difference in Crassula helmsii abundance between grazed and ungrazed plots.

question_details.query: For invasive plants like skunk cabbage and Crassula helmsii in small ponds, what are the most promising methods for achieving complete eradication?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For Crassula helmsii eradication in small ponds, several methods show promise. Salt water treatment has proven effective, with two replicated, controlled container trials and two before-and-after field trials in the UK finding that seawater eradicated Crassula helmsii (action 1288). Lightproof barriers using black sheeting or carpet strips showed significant results in five before-and-after studies in the UK, which found that covering Crassula helmsii eradicated or severely reduced plant cover, though progressive recolonization occurred at two sites where initial eradication was reported (action 1294). A combination approach using carpet covering followed by glyphosate herbicide treatment killed 80% of Crassula helmsii in one UK pond study (action 1313). For skunk cabbage eradication, physical removal methods show effectiveness but require sustained effort. A study in Switzerland found that annual physical removal of recently established skunk cabbage plants over five years removed the entire stock, while a study in the Netherlands found manual removal effective for small outbreaks of small-growing plants (action 1101). However, a German study reported that after four years of twice-yearly full removal, a large number of plants still needed to be removed annually (action 1101). Chemical control using herbicides shows mixed results for skunk cabbage. One UK study found that both glyphosate and 2,4-D Amine killed all skunk cabbage plants in test areas, but another UK study found that while 2,4-D amine at 9 litres/ha successfully eradicated skunk cabbage, glyphosate was unsuccessful and only achieved limited reduction in plant growth (action 1102).
summary_statements: For Crassula helmsii eradication in small ponds, several methods show promise.
Salt water treatment has proven effective for eradicating Crassula helmsii.
Two replicated, controlled container trials and two before-and-after field trials in the UK found that seawater eradicated Crassula helmsii.
Lightproof barriers using black sheeting or carpet strips showed significant results in five before-and-after studies in the UK.
Covering Crassula helmsii with lightproof barriers was found to eradicate or severely reduce plant cover.
Progressive recolonization of Crassula helmsii occurred at two sites where initial eradication with lightproof barriers was reported.
A combination approach using carpet covering followed by glyphosate herbicide treatment killed 80% of Crassula helmsii in one UK pond study.
For skunk cabbage eradication, physical removal methods show effectiveness but require sustained effort.
A study in Switzerland found that annual physical removal of recently established skunk cabbage plants over five years removed the entire stock.
A study in the Netherlands found manual removal of skunk cabbage was effective for small outbreaks of small-growing plants.
A German study reported that after four years of twice-yearly full removal of skunk cabbage, a large number of plants still needed to be removed annually.
Chemical control using herbicides shows mixed results for skunk cabbage.
One UK study found that both glyphosate and 2,4-D Amine killed all skunk cabbage plants in test areas.
Another UK study found that 2,4-D amine at 9 litres/ha successfully eradicated skunk cabbage.
In a UK study, glyphosate was unsuccessful in eradicating skunk cabbage and only achieved a limited reduction in plant growth.

question_details.query: Beyond direct removal, what alternative management strategies exist for controlling American bullfrog populations, and what is their effectiveness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, there are limited alternative management strategies for controlling American bullfrog populations beyond direct removal methods. Biological control using native predators represents one alternative approach, with one replicated, controlled study conducted in Belgium finding that the introduction of northern pike led to a strong decline in bullfrog tadpole numbers (action 1039). Habitat modification is mentioned as a potential strategy, but no evidence was captured on the effects of habitat modification on the control of American bullfrogs (action 1041). Collection of egg clutches is referenced as a management approach using bilge pumps or nets, but no evidence was captured on the effects of egg collection on American bullfrogs (action 1047). For context on the effectiveness of direct removal methods, studies show mixed results: one replicated, controlled study in the USA found that bullfrog populations rapidly rebounded following intensive removal of adults (action 1045), while removal programs can be effective when carried out as combination treatments, with one study in France finding significant reduction in adults and juveniles following removal of juveniles by trapping and shooting of metamorphosed individuals before reproduction (actions 1045, 1046). Prevention through reducing amphibian trade is mentioned, with one review finding that reducing trade in frog species through legislation allowed populations to recover from over-exploitation (action 824).
summary_statements: There are limited alternative management strategies for controlling American bullfrog populations beyond direct removal methods.
Biological control using native predators represents one alternative approach to controlling American bullfrog populations.
The introduction of northern pike led to a strong decline in bullfrog tadpole numbers in a study in Belgium.
Habitat modification is mentioned as a potential strategy for controlling American bullfrogs.
No evidence was captured on the effects of habitat modification on the control of American bullfrogs.
Collection of egg clutches using bilge pumps or nets is referenced as a management approach for American bullfrogs.
No evidence was captured on the effects of egg collection on American bullfrogs.
Studies on the effectiveness of direct removal methods for American bullfrogs show mixed results.
One study in the USA found that bullfrog populations rapidly rebounded following intensive removal of adults.
Removal programs for American bullfrogs can be effective when carried out as combination treatments.
One study in France found a significant reduction in adult and juvenile bullfrogs following removal of juveniles by trapping and shooting of metamorphosed individuals before reproduction.
Prevention through reducing amphibian trade is a mentioned strategy.
One review found that reducing trade in frog species through legislation allowed populations to recover from over-exploitation.

question_details.query: What methods are available for managing biofouling by Asian clams in industrial water systems, such as within pipes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several methods are available for managing biofouling by Asian clams in industrial water systems and pipes. Chemical treatments include dosing with biocides such as chlorine, potassium and copper which killed Asian clams in laboratory studies (Action 1118). Higher concentrations of chlorine and bromine, delivered at higher temperatures, shortened the time required to kill the Asian clams (Action 1118). Fat-coated particles called BioBullets could kill 100% of the Asian clams within pipes in Spanish irrigation systems (Action 1118). Temperature manipulation is effective, with temperatures of 36°C or higher killing Asian clams within or after four days (Action 1116). Mechanical approaches include regular cleaning of industrial pipes which was found to be an effective method of permanently removing Asian clams in Portugal (Action 1119). The addition of a sand filter was effective at reducing numbers of Asian clams (Action 1119). Suction dredging reduced Asian clam densities by 96% over two weeks with the reduction persisting for a year (Action 1120). Three types of dredges were equally effective at removing Asian clams, resulting in biomass reductions ranging from 74% to greater than 95% and density reductions ranging from 65% to 95% (Action 1120). High salinity exposure (18-34‰) killed 100% of Asian clams in laboratory conditions (Action 1115). However, reducing oxygen levels in water was not effective as Asian clams were resistant to extremely low oxygen levels regardless of water temperature or duration of exposure (Action 1113).
summary_statements: Several methods are available for managing biofouling by Asian clams in industrial water systems and pipes.
Chemical treatments include dosing with biocides such as chlorine, potassium and copper, which killed Asian clams in laboratory studies.
Higher concentrations of chlorine and bromine, delivered at higher temperatures, shortened the time required to kill the Asian clams.
Fat-coated particles called BioBullets could kill 100% of the Asian clams within pipes in Spanish irrigation systems.
Temperature manipulation is effective, with temperatures of 36°C or higher killing Asian clams within or after four days.
Mechanical approaches include regular cleaning of industrial pipes, which was found to be an effective method of permanently removing Asian clams in Portugal.
The addition of a sand filter was effective at reducing numbers of Asian clams.
Suction dredging reduced Asian clam densities by 96% over two weeks, with the reduction persisting for a year.
Three types of dredges were equally effective at removing Asian clams, resulting in biomass reductions ranging from 74% to greater than 95%.
Three types of dredges were equally effective at removing Asian clams, resulting in density reductions ranging from 65% to 95%.
High salinity exposure killed 100% of Asian clams in laboratory conditions.
Reducing oxygen levels in water was not effective for managing Asian clams.
Asian clams were resistant to extremely low oxygen levels regardless of water temperature or duration of exposure.

question_details.query: What factors, such as herbicide type or the use of adjuvants, influence the success of chemical control for invasive aquatic plants like water primrose and parrot's feather?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Several factors influence the success of chemical control for invasive aquatic plants like water primrose and parrot's feather:

**Herbicide Type for Water Primrose:**
Triclopyr TEA applied at 0.25% concentration killed 100% of young cultivated water primrose within two months (action 1139). Glyphosate controlled water primrose with 97% mortality when mixed with a non-oil based sticking agent and 100% mortality when combined with TopFilm (action 1139). Halosulfuron-methyl (Sempra) resulted in significant reduction in water primrose coverage (action 1139).

**Herbicide Type for Parrot's Feather:**
2,4-D reduced growth of parrot's feather and led to greater reduction compared to diquat, glyphosate or imazapyr (action 1606). The combined application of 2,4-D and MCPA completely eliminated parrot's feather (action 1606). Triclopyr reduced cover and led to greater reduction than glyphosate (action 1689). Other effective herbicides included carfentrazone-ethyl (action 1676), endothall (action 1681), diquat (action 1680), imazamox, imazapyr, glyphosate, gluphosinate-ammonium, flumioxazin, and florpyrauxifen-benzyl (action 1699). Some herbicides showed limited effectiveness: fluridone, clopyralid and copper chelate did not reduce growth (action 1699).

**Use of Adjuvants:**
For water primrose, glyphosate showed differential effectiveness depending on adjuvant type - 97% mortality with non-oil based sticking agent versus 100% mortality when combined with TopFilm (action 1139). For water primrose, glyphosate combined with surface active agent Cygnet-Plus followed by mechanical removal achieved 75% kill rate (action 1140).

**Application Factors:**
Concentration affects effectiveness, as demonstrated with triclopyr TEA at 0.25% concentration achieving complete mortality in water primrose (action 1139). Some studies showed that effectiveness can vary between laboratory and field conditions, with some herbicides showing reduced effectiveness in field applications compared to laboratory studies (actions 1680, 1681).
summary_statements: Several factors influence the success of chemical control for invasive aquatic plants like water primrose and parrot's feather.
Triclopyr TEA applied at 0.25% concentration killed 100% of young cultivated water primrose within two months.
Glyphosate controlled water primrose with 97% mortality when mixed with a non-oil based sticking agent.
Glyphosate controlled water primrose with 100% mortality when combined with TopFilm.
Halosulfuron-methyl (Sempra) resulted in a significant reduction in water primrose coverage.
2,4-D reduced the growth of parrot's feather.
2,4-D led to a greater reduction in parrot's feather growth compared to diquat, glyphosate or imazapyr.
The combined application of 2,4-D and MCPA completely eliminated parrot's feather.
Triclopyr reduced the cover of parrot's feather.
Triclopyr led to a greater reduction in parrot's feather cover than glyphosate.
Other effective herbicides for parrot's feather included carfentrazone-ethyl, endothall, diquat, imazamox, imazapyr, glyphosate, gluphosinate-ammonium, flumioxazin, and florpyrauxifen-benzyl.
Some herbicides such as fluridone, clopyralid and copper chelate did not reduce the growth of parrot's feather.
For water primrose, glyphosate showed differential effectiveness depending on the adjuvant type.
For water primrose, glyphosate achieved 97% mortality with a non-oil based sticking agent.
For water primrose, glyphosate achieved 100% mortality when combined with the adjuvant TopFilm.

Some herbicides show reduced effectiveness in field applications compared to laboratory studies.

question_details.query: How does the effectiveness of draining water bodies compare to using physical barriers for controlling invasive species like Asian clams and Crassula helmsii?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, there is no scientific documentation for the effectiveness of draining water bodies to control either Asian clams (action 1110) or Crassula helmsii (action 1303). In contrast, physical barriers show documented effectiveness for both species. For Asian clams, gas-impermeable barriers placed across lake bottoms significantly reduced their abundance (action 1117). For Crassula helmsii, lightproof barriers such as black sheeting or carpet strips eradicated or severely reduced plant cover in five UK studies, though progressive recolonization occurred at two sites where initial eradication was reported (action 1294). A combination approach using carpet covering followed by herbicide treatment achieved 80% plant mortality for Crassula helmsii (action 1313). Additionally, mechanical removal methods for Asian clams demonstrated high effectiveness, with suction dredging reducing densities by 96% over two weeks with persistence for a year, and various dredging types achieving 65-95% density reductions and 74-95% biomass reductions (action 1120).
summary_statements: There is no scientific documentation for the effectiveness of draining water bodies to control Asian clams.
There is no scientific documentation for the effectiveness of draining water bodies to control Crassula helmsii.
Physical barriers show documented effectiveness for controlling both Asian clams and Crassula helmsii.
For Asian clams, gas-impermeable barriers placed across lake bottoms significantly reduced the abundance of the clams.
For Crassula helmsii, lightproof barriers such as black sheeting or carpet strips eradicated or severely reduced plant cover in five UK studies.
Progressive recolonization by Crassula helmsii occurred at two sites where initial eradication was reported.
A combination approach using carpet covering followed by herbicide treatment achieved 80% plant mortality for Crassula helmsii.
Mechanical removal methods for Asian clams demonstrated high effectiveness.
Suction dredging reduced Asian clam densities by 96% over two weeks, with the reduction persisting for a year.
Various dredging types achieved 65-95% density reductions of Asian clams.
Various dredging types achieved 74-95% biomass reductions of Asian clams.

question_details.query: What is the extent of evidence for using biological control agents, such as host-specific herbivores or parasites, to manage invasive invertebrates like Procambarus crayfish and Ponto-Caspian gammarids?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence for using biological control agents to manage invasive invertebrates like Procambarus crayfish and Ponto-Caspian gammarids is extremely limited. For Ponto-Caspian gammarids, one replicated laboratory study in Canada found that an introduced parasitic mould reduced populations of an invasive shrimp (Action 1089). However, no evidence was captured for the use of predatory fish (Action 1087) or disease-causing organisms (Action 1090) to control Ponto-Caspian gammarids. For Procambarus crayfish, evidence focuses on predator encouragement rather than parasites or host-specific herbivores. Two replicated controlled studies in Italy found that eels fed on red swamp crayfish and reduced population size, and one replicated controlled study from France found that pike predated red swamp crayfish (Action 1030). A before-and-after study in Switzerland found that introducing predators combined with trapping significantly reduced red swamp crayfish populations in a pond, and a replicated controlled study from Italy demonstrated that trapping and predation in combination was more effective than predation alone (Action 1031). Regarding host-specific herbivores, no evidence was captured for their use against these specific invertebrate species. A replicated laboratory and field study in South America examined a South American weevil on floating pennywort, finding it caused more feeding lesions than on other plant species, but field results showed the weevil did not reduce floating pennywort biomass (Action 1123). No evidence was found for biological control using herbivores on other invasive plant species (Actions 1098, 1277). No studies were found that evaluated the effects of using biological control to manage invasive or problematic species on marine and freshwater mammal populations (Action 2852).
summary_statements: The evidence for using biological control agents to manage invasive invertebrates like Procambarus crayfish and Ponto-Caspian gammarids is extremely limited.
A replicated laboratory study in Canada found that an introduced parasitic mould reduced populations of an invasive shrimp.
No evidence was captured for the use of predatory fish to control Ponto-Caspian gammarids.
No evidence was captured for the use of disease-causing organisms to control Ponto-Caspian gammarids.
For Procambarus crayfish, evidence focuses on predator encouragement rather than parasites or host-specific herbivores.
Two replicated controlled studies in Italy found that eels fed on red swamp crayfish and reduced the crayfish population size.
One replicated controlled study from France found that pike predated red swamp crayfish.
A before-and-after study in Switzerland found that introducing predators combined with trapping significantly reduced red swamp crayfish populations in a pond.
A replicated controlled study from Italy demonstrated that trapping and predation in combination was more effective than predation alone.
Regarding host-specific herbivores, no evidence was captured for use against Procambarus crayfish or Ponto-Caspian gammarids.

A replicated laboratory and field study in South America that examined a South American weevil on floating pennywort found the weevil caused more feeding lesions on that plant than on other plant species.
Field results from a study in South America showed a South American weevil did not reduce floating pennywort biomass.
No evidence was found for biological control using herbivores on other invasive plant species.
No studies were found that evaluated the effects of using biological control to manage invasive or problematic species on marine and freshwater mammal populations.

question_details.query: What factors influence the success of chemical control for invasive plants, considering examples from skunk cabbage and water primrose management?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several factors influence the success of chemical control for invasive plants based on evidence from skunk cabbage and water primrose management. Herbicide type appears critical, as demonstrated by skunk cabbage studies where 2,4-D Amine at 9 litres/ha successfully eradicated skunk cabbage while glyphosate was unsuccessful at eradicating the same species, achieving only limited reduction in growth (Action 1102). For water primrose, herbicide concentration affects outcomes, with triclopyr TEA at 0.25% concentration achieving 100% mortality of young cultivated plants within two months (Action 1139). The addition of adjuvants enhances effectiveness, as shown in water primrose control where glyphosate achieved 97% mortality when mixed with a non-oil based sticking agent and 100% mortality when combined with TopFilm (Action 1139). Plant age and development stage influence control success, with young water primrose plants showing complete mortality to triclopyr TEA treatment (Action 1139). Combination approaches may improve outcomes, as demonstrated where glyphosate with Cygnet-Plus surface active agent followed by mechanical removal achieved 75% kill rate of water primrose (Action 1140), and combining herbicide application with physical removal and other actions like native plant promotion achieved 85-90% reduction in Peruvian primrose-willow coverage (Action 1140). Species-specific herbicide effectiveness varies significantly, with halosulfuron-methyl effectively reducing water primrose coverage without apparent toxicity to rice plants (Action 1139).
summary_statements: Several factors influence the success of chemical control for invasive plants.
The type of herbicide used is a critical factor, as demonstrated in skunk cabbage studies.
2,4-D Amine at 9 litres/ha successfully eradicated skunk cabbage.
Glyphosate was unsuccessful at eradicating skunk cabbage, achieving only a limited reduction in the plant's growth.
For water primrose, herbicide concentration affects the outcomes of chemical control.
Triclopyr TEA at a 0.25% concentration achieved 100% mortality of young cultivated water primrose plants within two months.
The addition of adjuvants enhances the effectiveness of herbicides.
In water primrose control, glyphosate achieved 97% mortality when mixed with a non-oil based sticking agent.
Glyphosate achieved 100% mortality of water primrose when combined with the adjuvant TopFilm.
A plant's age and developmental stage influence the success of chemical control.
Young water primrose plants showed complete mortality when treated with triclopyr TEA.
Using combination approaches for management may improve outcomes for invasive plant control.
Applying glyphosate with a surface active agent, followed by mechanical removal, achieved a 75% kill rate of water primrose.
Combining herbicide application with physical removal and the promotion of native plants achieved an 85-90% reduction in Peruvian primrose-willow coverage.
The effectiveness of an herbicide varies significantly depending on the plant species.
Halosulfuron-methyl effectively reduced water primrose coverage without causing apparent toxicity to nearby rice plants.

question_details.query: What management options can prevent the spread of invasive aquatic invertebrates like red swamp crayfish and Ponto-Caspian gammarids between water bodies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Management options to prevent the spread of invasive aquatic invertebrates like red swamp crayfish and Ponto-Caspian gammarids between water bodies include several physical and chemical approaches. Physical barriers can be effective, as concrete dams across streams with features specifically designed to prevent red swamp crayfish from crawling over them were found to be effective at containing population spread upstream (Action ID: 1037). Trapping and removal is another option, with food-baited traps being most effective for red swamp crayfish compared to pheromone baits, capturing over half of all crayfish caught (Action ID: 1029). For Ponto-Caspian gammarids, dewatering habitat by lowering water levels in sand killed three species of invasive freshwater shrimp, though one species required water content levels of 4% and below before being killed (Action ID: 1094). Chemical treatment methods have been tested but with limited field applicability - iodine solution, acetic acid, Virkon S and sodium hypochlorite killed invasive killer shrimp in laboratory conditions but were considered impractical for field application, while methanol, citric acid, urea, hydrogen peroxide and sucrose did not kill invasive killer shrimp (Action ID: 1095). For red swamp crayfish, the natural pyrethrum Pyblast at 0.05 mg/l concentration was effective but application to drained crayfish burrows was not effective (Action ID: 1036). Changing water salinity showed mixed results, with one study finding increased salinity killed the majority of invasive shrimp within five hours while another found it did not kill invasive killer shrimp (Action ID: 1091). Movement control can be achieved through water exposed to predatory fish, which slowed down or stopped movements of invasive freshwater shrimp, and carbonating water was found to stun invasive killer shrimp (Action ID: 1088). Lowering water pH was not effective for killing invasive killer shrimp (Action ID: 1093).
summary_statements: Management options to prevent the spread of invasive aquatic invertebrates like red swamp crayfish and Ponto-Caspian gammarids include several physical and chemical approaches.
Physical barriers, such as concrete dams across streams with features designed to prevent red swamp crayfish from crawling over them, can be effective at containing population spread upstream.
Trapping and removal is a management option for invasive aquatic invertebrates.
Food-baited traps were more effective for catching red swamp crayfish than pheromone baits, capturing over half of all crayfish caught in a study.
For Ponto-Caspian gammarids, dewatering habitat by lowering water levels in sand killed three species of invasive freshwater shrimp.
One species of invasive freshwater shrimp required water content levels of 4% and below before being killed by dewatering.
Chemical treatment methods have been tested but have shown limited field applicability.
In laboratory conditions, iodine solution, acetic acid, Virkon S, and sodium hypochlorite killed invasive killer shrimp.
The use of iodine solution, acetic acid, Virkon S, and sodium hypochlorite to kill invasive killer shrimp was considered impractical for field application.
Methanol, citric acid, urea, hydrogen peroxide, and sucrose did not kill invasive killer shrimp.
For red swamp crayfish, the natural pyrethrum Pyblast at a 0.05 mg/l concentration was effective.
The application of the natural pyrethrum Pyblast to drained crayfish burrows was not effective.
Changing water salinity to control invasive shrimp showed mixed results.
One study found that increased salinity killed the majority of invasive shrimp within five hours.
Another study found that increased salinity did not kill invasive killer shrimp.
Movement control can be achieved by exposing water to predatory fish, which slowed down or stopped the movements of invasive freshwater shrimp.
Carbonating water was found to stun invasive killer shrimp.
Lowering water pH was not effective for killing invasive killer shrimp.

question_details.query: For controlling invasive red swamp crayfish (Procambarus clarkii) in European ponds, what are some effective non-chemical management strategies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, several non-chemical management strategies for controlling invasive red swamp crayfish (Procambarus clarkii) in European ponds have been studied. Creating barriers has shown effectiveness, with a study from Spain (2007-2010) finding that concrete dams designed with features to prevent red swamp crayfish from crawling over them were effective at containing population spread upstream (Action 1037). Trapping and removal methods have been tested, with an Italian study finding that traps baited with food (tinned meat) were most effective at capturing red swamp crayfish compared to pheromone baits or no bait, with over half of all crayfish caught in food-baited traps (Action 1029). Encouraging predators shows promise, with studies from Italy demonstrating that eels can reduce red swamp crayfish population size by feeding on them, and a French study showing that pike also predate on red swamp crayfish (Action 1030). The combination of trapping with predator encouragement appears particularly effective, with a Swiss study showing significant population reduction when introducing predators combined with trapping, and an Italian study demonstrating this combination was more effective than predation alone (Action 1031). Male sterilization represents another potential approach, with an Italian laboratory study finding that X-ray exposure of male red swamp crayfish reduced offspring production by 43% (Action 1032). However, several strategies including draining waterways (Action 1034), electrofishing (Action 1035), and food source removal (Action 1033) currently lack sufficient research evidence to assess their effectiveness.
summary_statements: Several non-chemical management strategies for controlling invasive red swamp crayfish (Procambarus clarkii) in European ponds have been studied.
Creating barriers has shown effectiveness in controlling invasive red swamp crayfish.
Concrete dams designed with features to prevent red swamp crayfish from crawling over the dams were effective at containing the crayfish population's spread upstream.
Trapping and removal methods have been tested for controlling red swamp crayfish.
Traps baited with food, such as tinned meat, were most effective at capturing red swamp crayfish compared to pheromone baits or no bait.
Over half of all crayfish caught in a study were captured in food-baited traps.
Encouraging predators shows promise as a strategy for controlling red swamp crayfish.
Eels can reduce the population size of red swamp crayfish by feeding on the crayfish.
Pike are known to predate on red swamp crayfish.
The combination of trapping with predator encouragement appears to be a particularly effective management strategy for red swamp crayfish.
A significant reduction in the red swamp crayfish population was observed when introducing predators was combined with trapping.
Combining trapping with predation was more effective at controlling red swamp crayfish than predation alone.
Male sterilization represents a potential approach for controlling red swamp crayfish.
A laboratory study found that X-ray exposure of male red swamp crayfish reduced offspring production by 43%.
Draining waterways currently lacks sufficient research evidence to assess the strategy's effectiveness for controlling red swamp crayfish.
Electrofishing currently lacks sufficient research evidence to assess the strategy's effectiveness for controlling red swamp crayfish.
The removal of food sources currently lacks sufficient research evidence to assess the strategy's effectiveness for controlling red swamp crayfish.

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence for using physical barriers to control the movement of various invasive species, from crayfish to aquatic plants?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, the evidence for using physical barriers to control invasive species movement is limited but shows some effectiveness for specific species. For crayfish control, one before-and-after study conducted between 2007 and 2010 in Spain found that concrete dams across a stream, specifically designed with features to prevent red swamp crayfish from crawling over them, were effective at containing spread of the population upstream (action 1037). For aquatic plant control, evidence exists for lightproof barriers. Five before-and-after studies in the UK found that covering Crassula helmsii with black sheeting or carpet strips eradicated or severely reduced the cover of the plant, however C. helmsii was reported to have progressively recolonized two of the sites where it had been initially reported as eradicated (action 1294). One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled, before-and-after study in iris-invaded lakeshore marshes in Canada reported that covering plots with rubber sheeting after cutting back yellow iris prevented most vegetation regrowth in an intermittently flooded marsh, but had no clear effect in a permanently flooded marsh (action 3124). For parrot's feather control, no evidence was found for the use of lightproof barriers (action 1576). Barriers are also used to protect planted vegetation from interference, with studies showing that fences or barriers protecting freshwater wetlands planted with non-woody plants increased plant survival rates over 12-18 months after planting and affected plant community composition (action 3328).
summary_statements: The evidence for using physical barriers to control the movement of invasive species is limited.
Physical barriers show some effectiveness for controlling the movement of specific invasive species.

A study in Spain found that concrete dams across a stream, designed with features to prevent red swamp crayfish from crawling over the dams, were effective at containing the upstream spread of the crayfish population.
For aquatic plant control, evidence exists for the use of lightproof barriers.
Five before-and-after studies in the UK found that covering Crassula helmsii with black sheeting or carpet strips eradicated or severely reduced the cover of the plant.
The plant Crassula helmsii was reported to have progressively recolonized two of the sites where the plant had been initially reported as eradicated.
A study in Canada reported that covering plots with rubber sheeting after cutting back yellow iris prevented most vegetation regrowth in an intermittently flooded marsh.
Covering plots with rubber sheeting after cutting back yellow iris had no clear effect on vegetation regrowth in a permanently flooded marsh.
For parrot's feather control, no evidence was found for the use of lightproof barriers.
Barriers are used to protect planted vegetation from interference.
Studies show that fences or barriers protecting freshwater wetlands planted with non-woody plants increased plant survival rates over 12-18 months after planting.
Studies show that fences or barriers protecting freshwater wetlands planted with non-woody plants affected plant community composition.

question_details.query: What direct removal techniques are available for controlling invasive American bullfrogs and red-eared terrapins in North American ponds?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For American bullfrogs, several direct removal techniques are available: Double fyke nets are effective for catching bullfrog tadpoles in small shallow ponds (Action 1046), though catchability of adult bullfrogs using one double fyke net for 24 hours in small shallow ponds is very low (Action 1045). Bullfrog adults can be captured overnight using a single trap floating on the water surface (Action 1045). Shooting of metamorphosed individuals before reproduction has been found to significantly reduce the number of recorded adults and juveniles when carried out as part of combination treatment (Action 1045). Trapping for juvenile removal also resulted in significant reduction of adults and juveniles when part of combination treatment (Action 1046). Collection of egg clutches using bilge pumps or nets has been referenced but no evidence was captured on the effects of this technique (Action 1047). However, bullfrog populations rapidly rebound following intensive removal of adults (Action 1045). For red-eared terrapins, direct removal techniques include: Aranzadi turtle traps which were effective in trapping red-eared terrapins from a river but did not eradicate the population (Action 1055). Using sein nets to trap adults and juveniles was not successful in eradicating the population (Action 1055).
summary_statements: Double fyke nets are effective for catching American bullfrog tadpoles in small shallow ponds.
The catchability of adult American bullfrogs is very low when using one double fyke net for 24 hours in small shallow ponds.
Adult American bullfrogs can be captured overnight using a single trap floating on the water surface.
Shooting metamorphosed American bullfrogs before reproduction has been found to significantly reduce the number of recorded adults and juveniles when carried out as part of a combination treatment.
Trapping for the removal of juvenile American bullfrogs resulted in a significant reduction of adults and juveniles when conducted as part of a combination treatment.
The collection of American bullfrog egg clutches using bilge pumps or nets has been referenced as a removal technique.
No evidence was captured on the effects of collecting American bullfrog egg clutches using bilge pumps or nets.
American bullfrog populations rapidly rebound following the intensive removal of adults.
Aranzadi turtle traps were effective in trapping red-eared terrapins from a river.
The use of Aranzadi turtle traps did not eradicate the red-eared terrapin population.
Using sein nets to trap adult and juvenile red-eared terrapins was not successful in eradicating the population.

question_details.query: What are the documented outcomes of various physical and novel chemical control methods for floating pennywort?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Physical removal methods show mixed results. A study in Western Australia found that following a two-week program of physical removal of floating pennywort, the rate of growth exceeded the rate of removal (Action 1126). A study in the UK found that removal using a mechanical digger and monthly picking by hand greatly reduced the cover of floating pennywort but did not completely eradicate it (Action 1126). Chemical herbicide control shows varying effectiveness depending on the specific herbicide used. A controlled, replicated study in the UK found that the herbicide 2,4-D amine applied at 4.2 kg/ha achieved near to 100% mortality, compared with the herbicide glyphosate applied at 2.2 kg active ingredient/ha (without an adjuvant) which achieved negligible mortality (Action 1127). Combination treatments can be effective, as a before-and-after study in Western Australia found that a combination of cutting followed by glyphosate chemical treatment removed floating pennywort (Action 1128). Novel chemical methods have shown limited success. A controlled, replicated pilot study in The Netherlands found that hydrogen peroxide sprayed on potted floating pennywort plants resulted in curling and transparency of the leaves when applied at the highest tested concentration (30%), but this was still not sufficient to kill the plant (Action 1129). Physical flame treatment shows promise, as a controlled, replicated, pilot experiment in 2010 in The Netherlands found that flame treatments of 1, 2 or 3 seconds had a significantly negative and progressive impact on floating pennywort, and a 3 second repeat treatment after 11 days proved fatal (Action 1131).
summary_statements: Physical removal methods for floating pennywort show mixed results.
A study in Western Australia found that following a two-week program of physical removal of floating pennywort, the rate of growth exceeded the rate of removal.
A study in the UK found that removal of floating pennywort using a mechanical digger and monthly picking by hand greatly reduced the cover of the plant.
Removal of floating pennywort using a mechanical digger and monthly picking by hand did not completely eradicate the plant.
Chemical herbicide control for floating pennywort shows varying effectiveness depending on the specific herbicide used.
A controlled, replicated study in the UK found that the herbicide 2,4-D amine applied at 4.2 kg/ha achieved near to 100% mortality of floating pennywort.
A controlled, replicated study in the UK found that the herbicide glyphosate applied at 2.2 kg active ingredient/ha without an adjuvant achieved negligible mortality of floating pennywort.
Combination treatments for floating pennywort can be effective.
A before-and-after study in Western Australia found that a combination of cutting followed by glyphosate chemical treatment removed floating pennywort.
Novel chemical methods for controlling floating pennywort have shown limited success.

A controlled, replicated pilot study in The Netherlands found that hydrogen peroxide sprayed on potted floating pennywort plants resulted in curling and transparency of the leaves when applied at the highest tested concentration of 30%.
The application of hydrogen peroxide at a 30% concentration on floating pennywort was not sufficient to kill the plant.
Physical flame treatment for controlling floating pennywort shows promise.
A controlled, replicated, pilot experiment in The Netherlands found that flame treatments of 1, 2 or 3 seconds had a significantly negative and progressive impact on floating pennywort.
A 3-second repeat flame treatment on floating pennywort after 11 days proved fatal to the plant.
